body:
Hello up there. The following example compiles just fine:

```pyx
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
        if i&1 == 0:        # <-- NOTE
            pass
```

However when `i&1` is changed to `i%2` it fails to compile:

```pyx
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
        if i%2 == 0:        # <-- NOTE
            pass
```

gives

```
Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:1:5: Function declared nogil has Python locals or temporaries

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
            ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:2:13: Iterating over Python object not allowed without gil

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
                 ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:2:18: Calling gil-requiring function not allowed without gil

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
                 ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:2:18: Constructing Python tuple not allowed without gil

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
                  ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:2:19: Converting to Python object not allowed without gil

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
        if i%2 == 0:
              ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:3:15: Truth-testing Python object not allowed without gil

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
        if i%2 == 0:
              ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:3:15: Calling gil-requiring function not allowed without gil

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
cdef void func(int N) nogil:
    for i in range(N):
        if i%2 == 0:
           ^
------------------------------------------------------------

x.pyx:3:12: Calling gil-requiring function not allowed without gil

```

Cython version 0.29.16

Thanks beforehand,
Kirill

comment_data.body:
The difference between the two functions is way larger than it seems. `&` never fails, but division needs to raise an exception when dividing by 0. And that exception cannot be propagated to the caller due to the `void` return, so Cython will try to print it. All of this requires the GIL.

You can disable division safety by switching on `cdivision`.
@scoder, thanks for clarifying. What could be improved here is that division by non-zero constant never fails and so can never raise exception.
(it thus could be proved to not require the GIL at all and work out of the box)

> What could be improved here is that division by non-zero constant never fails and so can never raise exception.

True. I think at the time we didn't care because we knew that the C compiler would drop stupid code like `if (2 == 0) /* raise exception here */` anyway. But it does have an impact on `nogil` code.

PR welcome.

Hang on – this is already implemented:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/192925d8800421a791a783307118246b9c3d922f/Cython/Compiler/ExprNodes.py#L11530-L11533
Maybe it's really just the GIL checks that are wrong here?
@scoder thanks for reopening and for the code link. /cc @samaingw

Coming back to this, the issue seems to be the type inference for the loop variable. I guess it considers `%` an unsafe-enough operation to infer `i` as a Python variable, which then leads to the errors you got.

I think this can be improved. At least some cases of division and modulo should be considered safe.

PR welcome. See `MarkOverflowingArithmetic.visit_BinopNode()` in `TypeInference.py`. Tests can go into `overflow_check.pxi` (which is included and tested against different integer types) and `type_inference.pyx`. You can look at constant node values with `.has_constant_result()` and `.constant_result`.

rename.to: Allow division by non-0 constants in nogil code without safety checks.

rename.from: Allow division by non-0 constants in nogil code without safety checks.
rename.to: Infer C types for safe integer division cases

title: Infer C types for safe integer division cases
